poem:
**Popcorn in the Morning Paper**

Crinkled pages
report the crunch,
popped kernels in a
plastic bowl—
a backdrop,
a side note to
Emily in Paris,
to unseen friends.
But taste lingers,
salt on the lips,
a clandestine joy,
an addiction
best kept
unseen.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Australian supermarket pre-popped popcorn taste test: ‘Very addictive … I wouldn’t eat these publicly’ I think of popcorn like Emily in Paris, R&B music that’s not fast enough to dance to and work friends you never see outside work: best enjoyed as a background to whatever else is going on, such as a movie, mindless scrolling or your actual work. My life experience of popcorn has always been a snack or side dish, never the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
